document.title: An infinite family of multiplicatively independent bases of number systems in cyclotomic number fields

creator.contact: Manfred Madritsch1. Université de Lorraine, Institut Elie Cartan de Lorraine, UMR 7502, Vandoeuvre-lès-Nancy, F-54506, France;2. CNRS, Institut Elie Cartan de Lorraine, UMR 7502, Vandoeuvre-lès-Nancy, F-54506, France
Volker ZieglerJohann Radon Institute for Computational and Applied Mathematics (RICAM)Austrian Academy of SciencesAltenbergerstr. 69A-4040 Linz, Austria

abstract.name: Abstract.
abstract.p: Let ζk be a k-th primitive root of unity, ≥m+⁢ϕk1 an integer and ∈⁢ΦkX⁢ZX the k-th cyclotomic polynomial. In this paper we show that the pair +-mζkN is a canonical number system, with =N01…⁢Φkm. Moreover we also discuss whether the two bases +-mζk and +-nζk are multiplicatively independent for positive integers m and n and k fixed.

document.keywords: Canonical number systems, Radix representations, Diophantine equations, Nagell-Ljunggren equation
document.acknowledgements: The second author was supported by the Austrian Science Fund (FWF) under the project P 24801-N26.

para.p: Let ≥q2 be a positive integer. Then the pair q01…-q1 is a number system in the positive integers, i.e. every integer ∈nN has a unique representation of the form

Taking a negative integer ≤q-2 and 01…-q1 as set of digits one gets a number system for all integers Z. This concept of a number system was further extended to the Gaussian integers by Knuth []. He showed that the pairs +-1i01 and --1i01 are number systems in the Gaussian integers, i.e. every Gaussian integer ∈n⁢Zi has a unique representation of the form

where =b+-1i or =b--1i. It was shown by Kátai and Szabó [] that all possible bases for the Gaussian integers are of the form ±-mi with m a positive integer. These results were extended independently by Kátai and Kovács [] and Gilbert [], who classified all quadratic extensions.

A different point of view on the above systems is the following. Let P=+⁢pdXd⁢p-d1X-d1⋯⁢p1Xp0∈⁢ZX with =pd1 and =R⁢/⁢ZXPXZX. Then we call the pair PN with =N01…-p01 a canonical number system if every element ∈γR has a unique representation of the form

If P is irreducible and β is one of its roots, then R is isomorphic to ⁢Zβ. In this case we simply write βN instead of PN. By setting =P+Xq or =P+X2⁢2mX+m21 we obtain the canonical number systems in the integers and Gaussian integers from above, respectively.

Kovács [] proved that for any algebraic number field K and order =R⁢Zα of K there exists β such that βN is a canonical number system for R. Moreover he proved that if 1≤p-d1≤⋯≤p1≤p0, ≥p02 and if P is irreducible, then PN is a canonical number system in R. Pethő [] weakened the irreducibility condition by only assuming that no root of the polynomial is a root of unity.

Kovács and Pethő [] provided necessary and sufficient conditions on the pair βN to be a number system in ⁢Zα. A decade later Akiyama and Pethő [] significantly reduced the number of cases one has to check under the additional assumption that

Math.text: ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ d)@(absolute-value@(p _ i)) less p _ 0

para.p: Let us denote by ζk some primitive k-th root of unity. Since +i and -i are primitive fourth roots of unity, we can say that all the bases for the Gaussian integers are of the form +-mζ4, with ≥m1. Furthermore an easy computation shows that +-mζ3 are bases in ⁢Zζ3 for ≥m1. Thus our first result answers the question, whether +-mζk is a basis in ⁢Zζk.

p.text: Let >k2 and m be positive integers. If ≥m+⁢ϕk1, then +-mζkN is a canonical number system.

para.p: Our second result considers, whether these bases are multiplicatively independent. We call two algebraic integers α and β multiplicatively independent, if =αpβq has only the solution p=q=0 over the integers. Considering bases in the Gaussian integers Hansel and Safer [] proved that +-mi and +-ni are multiplicative independent for all m>n>0. Their motivation was a version of Cobham’s theorem [] for the Gaussian integers. Cobham’s theorem states that a set ⊂EN is m- and n-recognizable with m and n multiplicative independent integers if and only if the set E is a union of arithmetic progressions. This means that e.g. except for arithmetic progressions we are not able to deduce the base 3 expansion form the one in base 2.
In the present paper we want to generalize the result of Hansel and Safer [] on the multiplicative independence to bases of ⁢Zζk of the form +-mζk for ≥k3.

p.text: Let ≥k3 be a positive integer. Then the algebraic integers +-mζk and +-nζk are multiplicatively independent provided m>n>⁢Ck, where ⁢Ck is an effective computable constant depending on k.
Moreover, if k is a power of 235671113, 1719 or 23, then +-mζk and +-nζk are multiplicatively independent as long as m>n>0.

para.p: In order to prove Theorem one has to show that the Diophantine equation

Math.text: ((- m) + zeta _ k) ^ p = ((- n) + zeta _ k) ^ q

para.p: has no solution nmpq, with m>n>⁢Ck and pq are not both zero. Taking norms in () we obtain =⁢Φkmp⁢Φknq and therefore the Diophantine equation () becomes

Math.text: Phi _ k * m ^ p = eta ^ q

para.p: where Φk is the k-th cyclotomic polynomial and =η⁢Φkn. In case that p and q have greatest common divisor >d1 we take d-th roots and obtain equation () with p and q co-prime. Therefore we may assume that p and q are coprime and we deduce that η is a p-th power, i.e. we get an equation of the form =⁢Φkmyq with =yη/1p. Note that since we assume >mn⁢Ck the case =⁢Φkm-yq can be excluded. Indeed, we know that >⁢Φkm0 for m sufficiently large. In any case we obtain a Diophantine equation of the form

Math.text: Phi _ k * m = y ^ q

para.p: Equation () is closely related to the well-studied Nagell-Ljunggren equation

Math.text: formulae@((x ^ k - 1) / (x - 1) = list@(y ^ q, x), formulae@(y > 1, formulae@(q >= 2, k > 2.)))

para.p: If k is a prime, then the Diophantine equations () and () are identical and every solution to () yields a solution to (). Therefore we conjecture:

p.text: Let k be an odd prime. Then +-mζk and +-nζk are multiplicatively independent provided m>n>0.

para.p: Since it is widely believed that the Nagell-Ljunggren equation () has only the three solutions
this conjecture seems plausible. Note that none of these solutions to () implies a solution to (). We guess that even more is true and believe that the following question has an affirmative answer.

p.text: Given >k2 are +-mζk and +-nζk multiplicatively independent provided m>n>1?

para.p: We excluded the case that =n1 since for =k6 we have =+-1ζ6ζ3 and ζ3 and +-mζ6 are always multiplicatively dependent.

section.title: 2Canonical number systems and the proof of Theorem
section.toctitle: 2Canonical number systems and the proof of Theorem

para.p: The main tool in our proof is the following result due to Pethő [].

p.text: Let P=∑=j0d⁢pjXj∈⁢ZX with =pd1. If 0<p-d1≤p-d2≤⋯≤p0, ≥p02 and no root of P is a root of unity, then the pair PN is a canonical number system.

para.p: Since ζk is a primitive k-th root of unity +-mζk is a root of =⁢PX⁢Φk+mX. By Vieta’s formula we obtain

Math.text: p _ (phi * k - d) = (tilde@(p)) _ d = (sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ d element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ d)))

para.p: Here we identify elements of ⁢/ZkZ with their minimal representatives in Z, i.e. with the integers in the set 01…-k1 in the obvious way. In order to apply Lemma we have to prove that ≤~pd~p+d1. For a given ordered +d1-tuple a1<⋯<a+d1 there are +d1 possibilities to deduce an ordered d-tuple. Thus

Math.text: (d + 1) * (sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ (d + 1) element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ (d + 1)))) = (sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ d element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ d)) * (sum _ (list@(b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *, b not-equals list@(a _ 1, ldots, a _ d))))@(m - (zeta _ k) ^ b))

para.p: Therefore we get for <d⁢ϕk that

Math.text: (tilde@(p)) _ (d + 1) = (sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ (d + 1) element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ (d + 1))))
(tilde@(p)) _ (d + 1) = absent
(sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ (d + 1) element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ (d + 1))))

absent = (1 / (d + 1)) * (sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ d element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ d)) * (sum _ (list@(b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *, b not-equals list@(a _ 1, ldots, a _ d))))@(m - (zeta _ k) ^ b))

(1 / (d + 1)) * (sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ d element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ d)) * (sum _ (list@(b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *, b not-equals list@(a _ 1, ldots, a _ d))))@(m - (zeta _ k) ^ b))
absent = ((m * (phi * k - d)) / (d + 1)) * (sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ d element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ d)))
((m * (phi * k - d)) / (d + 1)) * (sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ d element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ d)))

- (1 / (d + 1)) * (sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ d element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ d)) * (sum _ (list@(b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *, b not-equals list@(a _ 1, ldots, a _ d))))@((zeta _ k) ^ b))

- (1 / (d + 1)) * (sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ d element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ d)) * (sum _ (list@(b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *, b not-equals list@(a _ 1, ldots, a _ d))))@((zeta _ k) ^ b))
absent >= ((tilde@(p)) _ d * m * (phi * k - d)) / (d + 1)
((tilde@(p)) _ d * m * (phi * k - d)) / (d + 1)

- (1 / (d + 1)) * absolute-value@((sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ d element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ d)) * (sum _ (list@(b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *, b not-equals list@(a _ 1, ldots, a _ d))))@((zeta _ k) ^ b)))

- (1 / (d + 1)) * absolute-value@((sum _ (a _ 1 less cdots less a _ d element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ 1)) * cdots * (m - (zeta _ k) ^ (a _ d)) * (sum _ (list@(b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *, b not-equals list@(a _ 1, ldots, a _ d))))@((zeta _ k) ^ b)))
absent >= ((tilde@(p)) _ d * m * (phi * k - d)) / (d + 1) - binomial@(phi * k, d) * (((m + 1) ^ d * (phi * k - d)) / (d + 1))
((tilde@(p)) _ d * m * (phi * k - d)) / (d + 1) - binomial@(phi * k, d) * (((m + 1) ^ d * (phi * k - d)) / (d + 1))

para.p: Note that in the first four lines in the inequality above all the sums over complex terms yield indeed real numbers. Further the “≥” signs are true due to the triangle inequality and trivial estimates of the form -m1≤-mζka≤+m1. Furthermore, by () we have

Math.text: (m + 1) ^ d * binomial@(phi * k, d) > (tilde@(p)) _ d > (m - 1) ^ d * binomial@(phi * k, d)

para.p: and therefore

Math.text: binomial@(phi * k, d) * ((m + 1) ^ d / (tilde@(p)) _ d) less ((m + 1) / (m - 1)) ^ d = (1 + 2 / (m - 1)) ^ d less e ^ 2

para.p: where we used that -m1≥⁢ϕk>d by our assumption. Altogether we obtain the inequality
Thus the coefficients are increasing if
We split our considerations into two cases whether ≤d-⁢ϕk2 or not.
Case 1: ≤d-⁢ϕk2. Together with our assumption that ≥m+⁢ϕk1 we get that the coefficients ~pd up to ~p-⁢ϕk1 are increasing if
Since ⁢ϕk only takes positive values a simple calculation yields that this is the case for ⁢ϕk≥-⁢2e23≈11.78.

On the contrary, since ⁢ϕk only takes even values except the value 1, we may assume ≤⁢ϕk10, which implies ≤d8. Plugging this into () yields that the coefficients are increasing provided m≥+e292≈11.89.

Finally computing all polynomials ⁢Φk+mx with +⁢ϕk1≤m≤11 by aid of a computer algebra system we see that in any case the coefficients ~pd are increasing. In fact we only have to check 92 polynomials, which are certainly to many for writing them down.
Case 2: =d-⁢ϕk1. Thus we are left to show that ≥p1p0, i.e.

Math.text: (product _ (a element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@(m - (zeta _ k) ^ a) >= (sum _ (b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@((product _ (list@(a element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *, a not-equals b)))@(m - (zeta _ k) ^ a))

para.p: Since

Math.text: 1 >= (phi * k) / (m - 1) = (sum _ (b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@(1 / (m - 1)) >= (sum _ (b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@(1 / (m - (zeta _ k) ^ b))

para.p: provided that ≥m+⁢ϕk1, this case is settled too.

The next requirement, in order to apply Lemma , is to show that no root of ⁢Φk+mX is a root of unity. Since we assume m≥+⁢ϕk1≥3. So all roots of ⁢Φk+mX have real part ≥2 and therefore cannot be roots of unity.
Finally we have to check that ≥p02. But by () we have p0≥-m1⁢ϕk≥2 provided ≥m3, which we assume.
Therefore ⁢Φk+Xm satisfies all assumptions of Lemma and Theorem is proved.
In case that ≤m-⁢ϕk1 we have <p0p1 and an application of Lemma is no longer possible. Indeed, we have

Math.text: 1 less= (phi * k) / (m + 1) = (sum _ (b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@(1 / (m + 1)) less (sum _ (b element-of ((Z / k) * Z) ^ *))@(1 / (m - (zeta _ k) ^ b))

para.p: and by the same arguments as in Case 2 above we obtain <p0p1. In case that =m⁢ϕk both situations ≤p1p0 and >p1p0 occur. For instance, in case that =m11 we have ≤p1p0 but in case that =m12 we have <p1p0. Therefore in view of the method of proof Theorem is best possible.
Before we start with the proof of Theorem , let us note that if p and q have a common factor d then by taking d-th roots on both sides of equation () we obtain

Math.text: (zeta _ k) ^ j * ((- m) + zeta _ k) ^ p = ((- n) + zeta _ k) ^ q

para.p: with =gcdpq1 and 0≤j<k.
We start with the proof of the first statement of Theorem . In view of the discussion below Theorem we consider the Diophantine equation

Math.text: f * x = y ^ q

para.p: where f is a polynomial with rational coefficients and with at least two distinct roots. Obviously () fulfills these requirements as soon as >k2. Due to Schinzel and Tijdeman [] (see also [, Theorem 10.2]) we know that for all solutions xyq to () with >y1, q is bounded by an effectively computable constant depending only on f. In view of Theorem we see that all solutions coming from () yield >y1 provided ≠n0. But it is also well known (see e.g. [, Theorem 6.1 and 6.2]) that for given ≥q2 all solutions xy to () satisfy <maxxyCfq, where Cfq is an absolute, effectively computable constant depending on f and q. Thus we conclude that =q1 in equation () if >mn⁢Ck, and ⁢Ck is an effectively computable constant only depending on k. Exchanging the roles of m and n we deduce that q=p=1 if >mn⁢Ck. But this yields the equation =⁢ζkj+-mζk+-nζk and taking norms on both sides gives =⁢Φkm⁢Φkn. Since ⁢Φkm is strictly increasing for m large enough we deduce that =mn which we excluded. Therefore the proof of the first part of Theorem is complete.

However, computing the constant ⁢Ck using the methods cited above will yield very huge constants even for small values of k. Therefore we will use a more direct approach in the proof of the second part.
We note that =⁢ΦnX⁢Φ/nqX/nq if q2|n. In particular, if =nqℓ we have

Math.text: Phi _ (q ^ ell) * X = Phi _ q * X ^ q ^ (ell - 1)

para.p: Let us start with powers of 2. In this case we have that =⁢Φ2ℓX+X2-ℓ11. Therefore the case that k is a power of 2 is deduced from the fact that the Diophantine equation
has no solution. This is a special case of Catalan’s equation =-XpYq1 which was completely solved by Mihǎilescu []. Note that this special case was already proved by Chao [].
In the next step we consider the case that k is a power of 3 or 6.

p.text: Let k be a power of 3 or 6. Then the two algebraic integers +-mζk and +-nζk are multiplicatively independent provided ≠nm and ∉nm0-1.

para.p: Let us consider equation () and let =Mm/k3 if 9|k, =Mm/k6 if 36|k and =Mm otherwise. Then equation () turns into

Math.text: (M ^ 2 plus-or-minus M) + 1 = ((2 * M plus-or-minus 1) / 2) ^ 2 + 3 / 4 = Y ^ q

para.p: where the “+” sign holds in case that k is a power of 3 and the “-” sign holds in case that k is a power of 6. Multiplying this equation by 4 and putting =X±⁢2M1 we get

Due to Luca and Tengely [] we know that =XYq11q and 3773 are the only solutions with ≥XYq1. The first solution yields ∈m0-1 which we have excluded and the second solution yields =M±18 or =M±19. Since both, 18 and 19, are not perfect powers we conclude that =k3 or =k6. We may recover m and n from the substitutions that led to equation (). Therefore we are left to check that in case that =k3 equation () has no solution with =m18-19, =n2-3, =q3 and =p1 and in case that =k6 equation () has no solution with =m-1819, =n-23, =q3 and =p1. This is of course easily done e.g. by a computer. ∎

We are left to the case that k is a power of 5711131719 or 23. Since every solution to () implies a solution to the Nagell-Ljunggren equation (), the following results due to Bugeaud, Hanrot and Mignotte [, Theorem 1 and 2] are essential in the proof of Theorem .

p.text: The Nagell-Ljunggren equation () has except the three solutions =xykq311527204218733 no further solution in case that

Math.text: q not-equals list@(17, 19)

para.p: Since the identity (), we get in case that =kPℓ is a prime power
with =xXP-ℓ1. If we assume now that =P5711 or 13 the only possible solutions to () imply that =q1. Exchanging the role of m and n we also obtain =p1 and equation () turns into

Math.text: (zeta _ k) ^ j * ((- m) + zeta _ k) = (- n) + zeta _ k

para.p: Taking norms yields
hence =mn, which we excluded. Therefore the we are left to the case that k is a power of 1719 or 23.

Before we consider the remaining cases we want to remind the reader that an integral basis for ⁢Zζk is given by 1ζk…ζk-⁢ϕk1 and therefore every algebraic integer ∈α⁢Zζk has a unique representation of the form

Math.text: alpha = ((sum _ (i = 0)) ^ (phi * k - 1))@(a _ i * (zeta _ k) ^ i)

para.p: with ∈aiZ for 0≤i<⁢ϕk. In the following we will expand the left and right side of equation () in various cases and bring the result into the unique form (). We will show below that on the left and right side of () the unique representations () do not match and conclude that no solution to () and hence no solution to () exists.

Assume that () has a solution mnpqj. In case that k is a power of 1719 or 23 Theorem implies that the only prime divisors of p and q in equation () are 1719 or 23 respectively. Therefore we are left to equation (), with =p1 and =q1719 or 23. Note that in case of =kq we have

Math.text: ((- n) + zeta _ k) ^ k = ((sum _ (i = 0)) ^ k)@((- n) ^ (k - i) * binomial@(k, i) * (zeta _ k) ^ i)
((- n) + zeta _ k) ^ k = absent
((sum _ (i = 0)) ^ k)@((- n) ^ (k - i) * binomial@(k, i) * (zeta _ k) ^ i)

para.p: Let us assume that 0≤j<-k2. Then with =p1 and =kq, either the coefficients ⁢pk0n and ⁢pk1n have to vanish simultaneously or the coefficients ⁢pk3n and ⁢pk4n vanish simultaneously. Since
as polynomials in n, the coefficients cannot vanish simultaneously. Similarly we obtain
where we consider the gcd taken over the polynomial ring ⁢Zn. Therefore we deduce =n0, a solution which we excluded.
Now consider the case that =kq and =j-k2. In this case equation () turns into

Math.text: - (m + 1) - zeta _ k - cdots - (zeta _ k) ^ (k - 2) = ((- n) + zeta _ k) ^ k = ((sum _ (i = 0)) ^ (k - 2))@(p _ (list@(k, i)) * n * (zeta _ k) ^ i)

para.p: Considering the coefficient of ζk we have
which cannot hold if >n1. Similarly for =k-j1 we obtain

Math.text: m + 1 + m * zeta _ k + cdots + m * (zeta _ k) ^ (k - 2) = ((- n) + zeta _ k) ^ k = ((sum _ (i = 0)) ^ (k - 2))@(p _ (list@(k, i)) * n * (zeta _ k) ^ i)

para.p: And in particular the coefficients of ζk and ζk2 have to be equal, i.e.
or equivalently
The last equation can only hold if n or k is zero or =+-⁢nkn20 which implies =k0 and =n2. Since all these options are excluded this case cannot occur.
Now let us consider the case that =kqℓ, with >ℓ1, and =q1719 or 23. If <j-⁢ϕk1 in () then all coefficients ζki with 0≤i<⁢ϕk of ⁢ζkj+-mζk vanish except exactly two. Indeed we have

Math.text: (zeta _ k) ^ j * ((- m) + zeta _ k) = (- m * (zeta _ k) ^ j) + (zeta _ k) ^ (j + 1)

para.p: On the right side of () all the coefficients of ζki with 0≤i≤q do not vanish, i.e. a contradiction.
In case that =j+⁢ϕkr for some 0≤r<-k⁢ϕk1=-q-ℓ11 we have

Math.text: ((- m) + zeta _ k) * (zeta _ k) ^ j = ((- m) + zeta _ k) * (- (zeta _ k) ^ r - (zeta _ k) ^ (r + q ^ (ell - 1)) - (zeta _ k) ^ (r + 2 * q ^ (ell - 1)) - cdots - (zeta _ k) ^ (r + (q - 2) * q ^ (ell - 1))) = (((- m * (zeta _ k) ^ r) + (zeta _ k) ^ (r + 1)) - cdots - m * (zeta _ k) ^ (r + (q - 2) * q ^ (ell - 1))) + (zeta _ k) ^ (r + 1 + (q - 2) * q ^ (ell - 1))

para.p: i.e. there exist non vanishing coefficients of ζki with >iq. But on the right side of () all coefficients of ζki vanish for >iq and again no solution is possible.
We are left to the two cases that =j-⁢ϕk1 and =j-k1. In both cases it is easy to see that ⁢ζkj+-mζk has non vanishing coefficients of ζki for >iq and we deduce again a contradiction.
The authors want to thank Shigeki Akiyama (University of Tsukuba) for pointing them to the refinement of Pethő [, Theorem 7.1].
